author: Billy Stockwell, Sana Noor Haq
title: Gaza: Children are drinking from puddles and wading through sewage pools, as Israel pummels water systems | CNN
text:
CNN ‚Äî Guns swinging from their hips, two soldiers in black combat boots and green tactical clothing appear to wire explosives to pumps at the Canada Water reservoir in Rafah, southern Gaza.
Moments later, an orange blaze tears through the critical facility in the Tal al-Sultan neighborhood, as ribbons of grey smoke erupt into the sky.
The blast was captured in a now deleted video , which was reportedly shared by an Israeli soldier on Instagram and geolocated by CNN. Satellite imagery shows that the reservoir was damaged between July 26 and July 27. Destroyed buildings are visible in the surrounding area.
The reservoir could hold 3 million liters of water and was central to the treatment and distribution of water in the Rafah Governate, according to the UN‚Äôs Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), providing water for 150,000 people prior to October 7, when the war began.
When asked about the incident captured on camera, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) told CNN that its troops had been operating in the Tal al-Sultan area for several weeks to ‚Äúdismantle terrorist infrastructures and eliminate terrorists, whilst taking feasible measures in order to mitigate damage to civilian structures.‚Äù
It added that it examines reports of videos posted to social media and handles them with disciplinary measures. The IDF said the incident was under review by the Fact Finding and Assessment Mechanism, ‚Äúan independent investigative mechanism outside the chain of command entrusted with investigating exceptional events in warfare.‚Äù
Maxar Technologies
Maxar Technologies Satellite images show Canada Water reservoir in Rafah, southern Gaza, on July 18 (left) and July 30 (right). ¬©2024 Maxar Technologies There have been many water facilities damaged or destroyed by Israel‚Äôs 10-month-long assault in Gaza, according to the UN and various other international bodies, compounding the civilian population‚Äôs suffering, risking the spread of disease and leading human rights experts to accuse Israel of using water supply as a weapon .
The destruction of the Canada Water reservoir ‚Äúis certainly a breach of international humanitarian law (IHL),‚Äù Mark Zeitoun, director general of the Geneva Water Hub, a Swiss institute specializing in hydro-diplomacy, told CNN.
‚ÄúIHL is meant to protect against indiscriminate attacks on the civilian population or the objects they depend upon (for) survival,‚Äù he said.
Even before the controlled explosion in late July, the Israeli siege drained fuel and electricity supplies needed to power the Canada Water reservoir and other water systems in the city, according to Rafah‚Äôs mayor, Ahmed Al-Sofi, causing severe shortages.
‚ÄúRafah was already suffering from water shortages,‚Äù Al-Sofi told CNN in July. ‚ÄúThe city of Rafah is a city struck by destruction, hunger and thirst.‚Äù
The amount of water available in Gaza works out at 4.74 liters of water (1 gallon) per person per day, Oxfam reported in July, adding that this is ‚Äújust under a third of the recommended minimum in emergencies and less than a single toilet flush.‚Äù The international nonprofit has accused Israel of using water as a ‚Äúweapon of war,‚Äù saying Palestinians in Gaza have ‚Äúalmost no water to drink, let alone to bathe, cook, or clean.‚Äù
Extreme summer heat in Gaza is making a desperate shortage of water even worse for Palestinians already stalked by famine and struggling with repeated displacement.
This June was the hottest on record in Israel, according to the Israel Meteorological Service. Temperatures in Negba, a few miles north of Gaza, reached 39.4 C (103F) in the middle of the month, according to CNN meteorologists.
Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza has reduced supplies of fuel, chlorine and spare parts, stifling water production, purification and sewage pumping, according to the UN. Around 70% of all water and sanitation facilities in Gaza have been destroyed or damaged, the WASH Cluster, a United Nations-led group that coordinates humanitarian efforts for water, sanitation and hygiene, said on July 24, citing satellite analysis from the UN Satellite Centre.
Palestinian children cool off and fill up water jugs in the Nuseirat refugee camp, in central Gaza, amid a heatwave on June 9, a day after a deadly operation by Israeli forces to rescue hostages. Majdi Fathi/NurPhoto/Getty Images COGAT, the Israeli agency responsible for approving aid into Gaza, told CNN in a statement that Israel allows and facilitates the ‚Äúunlimited entry‚Äù of water tanks and fuel supplies into Gaza. It added that there has been a ‚Äúcontinual effort‚Äù since the start of the war to facilitate the repair and extension of water wells, desalination facilities and water mains.
But several Palestinians told CNN they are forced to make hazardous journeys in search of water, risking exposure to Israeli attacks. Two people told CNN they had witnessed physical violence and even killing at public distribution points as people fight for scant resources. Those displaced to makeshift camps described scenes of sewage spilling into the streets and children drinking from puddles.
More than 1.7 million cases of infectious diseases have been recorded in Gaza, according to the Ministry of Health there. Traces of the highly infectious polio virus ‚Äì transmitted through faeces, and contaminated water or food ‚Äì were found in a 10-month-old child in the central Gazan city of Deir al-Balah earlier this month. The child was later paralyzed due to the disease, the UN said on August 23.
World Health Organization (WHO) testing discovered the virus in sewage samples in Gaza in July, putting thousands of Palestinians at risk of contracting a disease that can cause paralysis.
After the Gaza Ministry of Health declared a polio epidemic last month, the WHO warned that ongoing Israeli bombardment had stifled vaccination efforts in Gaza . They are now calling for a halt to the fighting to allow for an effective vaccination drive.
Widower Alaa Riyad says he treks many miles every day under the glare of the sun to collect water for his family, in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza.
The 42-year-old told CNN that he became ‚Äúfather and mother‚Äù to his children after his wife and 18 other relatives were killed by Israeli bombardment several months ago.
‚ÄúWe have found worms in the water more than once,‚Äù he told CNN. ‚ÄúWhat can we do?‚Ä¶ There is no life for us.‚Äù
Israeli attacks in the strip have killed more than 40,200 Palestinians and injured about 93,000 since the war started, according to the Ministry of Health in Gaza. The Israeli military launched its aerial and ground assault in Gaza after the militant group Hamas attacked southern Israel on October 7, killing around 1,200 people and abducting more than 250, according to Israeli authorities.
‚ÄòNear complete destruction of all water infrastructure‚Äô Gaza‚Äôs water crisis has been building for decades. In 2017, the UN‚Äôs children‚Äôs agency, UNICEF, said that 95% of water from Gaza‚Äôs sole aquifer was ‚Äúunfit for human consumption,‚Äù due to over-extraction, seawater infiltration and sewage contamination.
In 2021, about 90% of Gaza‚Äôs water came from groundwater wells drawing water from that aquifer, according to the Palestinian Water Authority. The remaining 10% came mostly from desalination plants and Israel‚Äôs national water company, Mekorot, via three pipelines.
But since early summer, Gaza‚Äôs municipal wells and desalination plants (two out of three of which are functioning) have operated at an average of around 15% and 22% capacity, respectively, according to CNN analysis of WASH Cluster data.
Wim Zwijnenburg, who investigates the environmental impact of conflicts for the Dutch peace organization PAX, told CNN the level of damage done to Gaza‚Äôs water systems is ‚Äúthe most severe we‚Äôve seen so far in any conflict in the last 10 years, probably even longer.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre seeing so far‚Ä¶ is the near-complete destruction of all water infrastructure, which includes water pumping stations, water wells, the whole piping system in Gaza,‚Äù Zwijnenburg said. ‚ÄúThe few functioning pumps that are still operating, the quality of the water is so bad‚Ä¶ (But) people have no choice but to drink it.‚Äù
Within the first week of the war, Saaed Al-Madhoun, an emergency response manager for the humanitarian agency CARE International, was forced to flee an Israeli incursion with his family near their home in Gaza City, which was later flattened by bombardment.
The aid worker is haunted by ‚Äúconstant fear and uncertainty,‚Äù as the threat of Israeli attacks loom over his wife and five children, aged between 1 and 13 years old. They are displaced in miserable conditions in Deir al-Balah, where the entire family survives on just 20 liters of water per day ‚Äì less than the minimum of 3 liters per person needed for survival, according to UNICEF .
‚ÄúMost of the water we access is not potable‚Ä¶ it often has a salty or metallic taste,‚Äù he said in testimony relayed to CNN by CARE International. ‚ÄúI have seen children drinking from puddles.‚Äù
‚ÄòCompletely miserable‚Äô conditions in tent camps Barbed wire and concrete slabs sink into huge pools of green, sewage-contaminated water in Khan Younis, southern Gaza. Footage filmed by a journalist working for CNN shows residents tiptoeing through streams of muddy water pouring through the once-vibrant neighborhood.
The Israeli offensive has displaced up to 1.9 million people ‚Äì nearly the entire population ‚Äì in Gaza, according to the UN . People in sprawling tent camps say they can barely access potable water or sanitation facilities in areas polluted by raw sewage and teeming with bugs . Women endure several menstrual cycles without washing, according to the UN . Others queue in the heat to use toilets at overwhelmed hospitals ‚Äì or risk being chased by dogs to use washrooms in the middle of the night. The UN previously recorded one improvised shelter with only 25 toilets for 14,000 people inside and 59,000 outside.
Palestinians told CNN they must prioritize scarce water supplies for consumption instead of bathing, washing clothes or cleaning dishes. Parents told CNN they struggle to find enough gas or fuel to boil and sterilize water, increasing the risk of illness. Some give their children food that requires minimal water for preparation ‚Äì but offers poor nutritional value. Others describe water contaminated during transportation in unclean tanks.
Children walk through pools of green, sewage-contaminated water in Khan Younis, southern Gaza. CNN Mohammed Hamouda, a health worker displaced in Deir al-Balah, told CNN he and his family, including his three young children, have suffered from diarrhea and abdominal cramps due to consumption of dirty water.
‚ÄúWe get the water supposedly clean and drinkable,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut gastrointestinal diseases and intestinal diseases occur‚Ä¶ We do not know that it is unclean until after we use it,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúObtaining clean water is difficult. Getting water for bathing is more difficult. Finding a toilet to relieve oneself is also very difficult.‚Äù
Muslims cannot find enough water to make ablution before prayer, a necessity for those seeking moments of relief through faith .
Children suffer from skin rashes, expectant mothers face stillbirth risk Asma struggles to distract her children from the stinging pain of blisters and itchiness of head lice. The Palestinian mother is staying with seven relatives in Deir al-Balah, where insects crawl between the folds of their tent.
‚ÄúIn the tents we have‚Ä¶ an unimaginable quantity of insects, pincher bugs and cockroaches,‚Äù she said, in an account relayed to CNN by CARE International. ‚ÄúWe get tired trying to cool and fan ourselves.‚Äù Asma‚Äôs last name has been withheld by CARE International to protect her identity.
‚ÄúMy children are sick, and we can‚Äôt even find medical treatment,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúWe have no shampoo, or detergent to wash our clothes‚Ä¶ What are we supposed to do?‚Äù
A Palestinian girl is diagnosed with a skin infection in Gaza, on July 26. Health workers say children are catching skin infections due to contaminated water and a lack of access to sanitation facilities. Dawoud Abo Alkas/Anadolu/Getty Images Chronic water shortages will compound ‚Äúall the existing fragility‚Äù among the population, according to Tanya Haj-Hassan, a pediatric intensive care doctor working with M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res (MSF), also known as Doctors Without Borders, especially for the most vulnerable.
The stress of war paired with water shortages increases the risk of stillbirth , pre-term delivery and blood clots for pregnant women in Gaza , Haj-Hassan said. Breastfeeding women are less likely to produce enough milk for newborns, potentially causing malnourishment. Those who can access sparse supplies of powdered infant formula may not find clean water to make up bottles, compounding the risk of illness, Haj-Hassan added.
Sustained restrictions on aid Israel‚Äôs COGAT told CNN they have facilitated the entry of 48,670 tons of water aid into Gaza since the war began, adding that they have provided 14 forklift trucks to assist with aid collection at the Kerem Shalom border crossing between Gaza and Israel, as well as broadening supply routes and increasing operating hours for aid collection.
But relief workers say what‚Äôs coming in is not nearly enough to respond to soaring needs, blaming Israel for sustained aid restrictions, blocked access to parts of the north , destruction of roads and attacks on relief convoys . Humanitarian workers and government officials told CNN in March that Israeli officials were repeatedly rejecting much needed aid, including water purification tablets and filtration systems, at entry points to Gaza. COGAT described the testimony given to CNN at the time as ‚Äúfalse accusations.‚Äù
Sham Abu Tabaq, age five, saw her father and sister shot dead in front of her. CNN Related article She says Israeli military killed her husband and daughter. Then soldiers brought her to an Israeli hospital
Liz Allcock, head of protection at the UK-based NGO Medical Aid for Palestinians, told CNN she saw ‚Äúthousands and thousands‚Äù of bottles of water sitting at the Kerem Shalom border crossing on July 3.
Several Palestinians told CNN that scarcity, the risks involved in transporting water, and fuel shortages had driven up the cost of water to unaffordable levels. Some say the absence of regulation means water supplied by aid agencies is sold on the black market for an inflated cost.
In some areas, water has risen from $7 for 1,000 liters (about 264 gallons) to $45 to $50, Haj-Hassan said. Hamouda, the father-of-three displaced in Deir al-Balah, said the daily cost of water for him and his family has risen from one-third of a dollar in October to $2.
Raed Radwan, a father displaced to a tent in Deir al-Balah told CNN that he was constantly worried about keeping his family cool and hydrated. His five-month-old daughter recently suffered heatstroke, and he had no cold water to give her.
‚ÄúFor nine months, we have been enduring the ongoing water crisis‚Ä¶ I hope there will be a solution to the water problem because I can no longer handle it. I am mentally and physically exhausted,‚Äù he said in July.
CNN‚Äôs Gianluca Mezzofiore, Abeer Salman, Tareq El Helou, Ibrahim Dahman and Lauren Izso contributed reporting.

title: The Ultimate Guide to Eucalyptus Silk Sheets: Benefits, Care, and Buying Tips - Bee in Motion
text:
The Ultimate Guide to Eucalyptus Silk Sheets: Benefits, Care, and Buying Tips November 7, 2024 , News Eucalyptus silk sheets are crafted from fibers extracted from the wood pulp of eucalyptus trees. These fibers are processed in a sustainable, closed-loop system that minimizes waste and recycles water, making eucalyptus silk a more environmentally friendly option than traditional cotton and even bamboo. Eucalyptus silk sheets are particularly known for their softness, just like traditional silk or high-thread-count cotton, while also being more breathable, hypoallergenic, and moisture-wicking.
Benefits of Eucalyptus Silk Sheets
1. Softness and Comfort
Eucalyptus silk sheets are known for their silky, smooth texture, typically described as even softer than cotton and linen. The fibers are extremely-fine and tightly woven, creating a luxuriously smooth and soft surface that feels gentle on the skin. This makes them a wonderful alternative for individuals with sensitive skin or anyone looking for a more comfortable sleep experience.
2. Temperature Regulation
One of the standout options of eucalyptus silk sheets is their natural temperature-regulating properties. Unlike traditional cotton sheets that will trap heat, eucalyptus fibers are highly breathable and moisture-wicking. They soak up and release moisture to keep you cool in the summertime and warm in the winter, making them supreme for all seasons and especially helpful for hot sleepers.
3. Hypoallergenic and Skin-Friendly
Eucalyptus silk sheets are hypoallergenic, that means they‚Äôre less likely to trigger allergies. They resist dust mites, mold, and different common allergens, making them splendid for individuals with asthma, allergic reactions, or different respiratory sensitivities. Additionally, the smooth surface of eucalyptus fibers reduces friction towards the skin, which can assist forestall irritation and even reduce hair breakage.
4. Eco-Friendly and Sustainable
Eucalyptus silk is an environmentally friendly various to different bedding materials. Eucalyptus timber require less water and pesticides to grow compared to cotton, and the production process for eucalyptus fiber is closed-loop, which means it reuses water and minimizes waste. Many brands additionally source their eucalyptus timber from sustainably managed forests, adding another layer of environmental benefit.
5. Durability
Eucalyptus silk sheets are highly durable and immune to pilling, making them a long-lasting investment. With proper care, they keep their softness and structural integrity over time, giving you years of luxurious sleep. Their durability makes them an attractive option for people who need high-quality bedding that won‚Äôt should be replaced frequently.
Tips on how to Care for Eucalyptus Silk Sheets
Proper care is essential to maintaining the softness, coloration, and durability of eucalyptus silk sheets. Right here‚Äôs find out how to keep them looking and feeling their greatest:
1. Wash with Care
Machine-wash eucalyptus silk sheets on a gentle or delicate cycle with cold water to prevent fiber damage. Keep away from utilizing bleach or harsh detergents, as these can break down the fibers and cause color fading. Instead, go for a mild, eco-friendly detergent.
2. Avoid High Heat
High heat can weaken eucalyptus fibers and cause shrinking, so it‚Äôs finest to air-dry your sheets or tumble dry them on a low-heat setting. To stop wrinkles, remove them from the dryer while they‚Äôre slightly damp and smooth them out before folding or putting them on the bed.
3. Store Properly
When not in use, store your eucalyptus silk sheets in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Exposure to UV rays can cause colour fading, so keeping them in a drawer or covered space will help them maintain their vibrancy.
4. Reduce Chemical Exposure
Keep away from using material softeners, as they‚Äôll go away residues that may intervene with the moisture-wicking properties of eucalyptus fibers. Equally, keep away from using sturdy chemical products round your sheets to preserve their natural breathability and softness.
Buying Ideas: What to Look for in Eucalyptus Silk Sheets
When shopping for eucalyptus silk sheets, consider these key factors to make positive you‚Äôre getting the perfect quality and worth:
1. Certification and Source
Look for sheets made from Tencel‚Ñ¢ Lyocell fibers, as these are produced in a sustainable and eco-friendly manner. Reputable brands typically embody certifications like OEKO-TEX¬Æ or FSC¬Æ (Forest Stewardship Council), which be sure that the sheets meet high environmental and safety standards.
2. Thread Count
While thread rely is a significant factor for cotton sheets, it‚Äôs less essential for eucalyptus silk. High-quality eucalyptus sheets typically fall between 300-four hundred thread count. Don‚Äôt be swayed by ultra-high thread counts, as they don‚Äôt essentially mean a better product.
3. Fit and Measurement
Eucalyptus sheets can typically shrink slightly, so remember to check the sizing. If attainable, look for sheets labeled as ‚Äúdeep pocket‚Äù or ‚Äúextra deep‚Äù to make sure they fit well on thicker mattresses or with mattress toppers.
4. Value and Warranty
Eucalyptus silk sheets tend to be more expensive than normal cotton sheets as a consequence of their distinctive benefits and production process. While the initial investment is higher, their durability and environmental benefits can make them worth the price. Look for brands that provide warranties or satisfaction ensures as an added layer of security.
5. Reviews and Brand Popularity
Finally, check critiques from different clients to gauge quality and durability. Established brands often have a robust repute for producing high-quality eucalyptus sheets, so researching before you buy may help make sure you‚Äôre satisfied with your purchase.
Conclusion
Eucalyptus silk sheets offer an opulent, eco-friendly bedding option that mixes softness, temperature regulation, hypoallergenic properties, and durability. They‚Äôre perfect for anyone seeking sustainable comfort with minimal environmental impact. By selecting high-quality sheets, following the care guidelines, and considering the factors above, you‚Äôll enjoy years of comfort and restful sleep on eucalyptus silk sheets. Whether or not you‚Äôre a hot sleeper, environmentally conscious, or just looking to upgrade your bedding, eucalyptus silk sheets are a worthwhile investment.

text: NEW YORK ( LifeSiteNews ) ‚Äî CatholicVote president Brian Burch requested New York Attorney General Letitia James and New York County District Attorney Alvin Bragg to open an investigation of the transgender activists who deceived and desecrated the iconic St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral during last week‚Äôs funeral for a transgender atheist . On February 15, transgender activist and prostitute ‚ÄúCecilia Gentili,‚Äù a man who ‚Äúidentified‚Äù as a woman, was celebrated at St. Patrick‚Äôs by hundreds of people dressed in scandalous clothing. Burch argued that the activists committed a hate crime with their open mockery of the Catholic faith within America‚Äôs most important Catholic cathedral and committed criminal trespass by obtaining access to the cathedral for the funeral through intentional deception, both in violation of current New York law. ‚ÄúAccording to both media reports and video footage readily available online, activists admit to withholding from cathedral administrators the full intent and purpose of their gathering,‚Äù Burch wrote. ‚ÄúIndeed, the Archdiocese of New York has publicly affirmed that they ‚Äòhad no idea our welcome and prayer would be degraded in such a sacrilegious and deceptive way.‚Äô The deception employed to gain access to St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral in order to hold a ceremony that profaned that holy place and mocked the Catholic religion cries out for justice.‚Äù READ: Cardinal Dolan says Harrison Butker sent him letter condemning ‚Äòtransgender funeral‚Äô at St. Patrick‚Äôs Citing New York‚Äôs Penal Law Sec. 485.05.1(a), and Penal Law Sec. 485.3., Burch noted that ‚Äúunder New York‚Äôs hate crimes law, selecting the victim of a criminal trespass based on a religion or religious practice is a hate crime.‚Äù ‚ÄúNew York‚Äôs courts have recognized that those who gain access to property by deception are liable for criminal trespass. People v. Segal, 78 Misc.2d 955 (1974),‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúThe outrageous sacrilege perpetrated at St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral is indeed a hate crime. Video footage shows that transgender activists intentionally used deception to obtain permission to enter St. Patrick‚Äôs and the facts show that access was used to desecrate that sacred space and mock Catholic faith and morals. Again, the pastor of St. Patrick‚Äôs has confirmed that they were not told the nature and purpose of the offensive stunt that was planned,‚Äù Burch wrote. READ: Faithful Catholics urge bishops to stop Fiducia Supplicans in light of St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral scandal Voicing the outrage of Catholics in New York and throughout the country, Burch told James to bring to justice the ‚Äútrans‚Äù activists who made mockery of the Catholic faith so vilely. ‚ÄúWe urge you to act quickly and resolutely to address this grave injustice, the very sort of vicious abuse that New York‚Äôs Hate Crimes Act was designed to prevent,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúOn behalf of millions of Catholics nationwide, we are asking for your help to vindicate the rights and dignity of Catholic New Yorkers, and indeed, the countless Catholics throughout this nation who regard St. Patrick‚Äôs as one of their most revered holy places.‚Äù ‚ÄúI urge you to defend the rights and dignity of Catholic New Yorkers and the tens of thousands of Catholics from throughout this great nation who visit St. Patrick‚Äôs to honor the saint and practice their faith each year.‚Äù READ: Catholics to hold Rosary rally at St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral after scandalous ‚Äòtransgender funeral‚Äô Members of Tradition, Family and Property (TFP) are organizing a Rosary rally to make reparation for the sacrilegious pro-LGBT funeral. ‚ÄúMocking everything sacred, the service looked like a Drag Queen Show, applauding sin, ridiculing the Church, and defiling the house of God,‚Äù a TFP flyer for the event said. A LifeSite petition launched in response to the event, which organizers have called a political protest, is urging Cardinal Timothy Dolan to exorcise the cathedral. As of the publication of this article, more than 14,000 people have added their signatures to the petition, which can be signed here .

title: Andrew Tate‚Äôs online university hacked with emails & private chat logs leaked - Dexerto
text:
Entertainment
Uncategorized Andrew Tate‚Äôs online university hacked with emails & private chat logs leaked Eleni Thomas ‚ùò Published: 2024-11-22T05:34:08 Instagram: Andrew Tate/The Real World Andrew Tate‚Äôs online University has been hacked, and hundreds of thousands of emails and private chat logs have been leaked online.
As first reported by The Daily Dot , content creator and online personality Andrew Tate was the subject of a major hack. His online University, The Real World, was infiltrated, and thousands of private records were leaked online.
While not a University in the conventional sense, The Real World, formerly known as Hustler‚Äôs University , offers its users ‚Äúadvanced training and mentoring‚Äù about earning money.
Article continues after ad The website‚Äôs home page states that ‚ÄúMoney making is a skill‚Äù and that it aims to ‚Äúteach [users] how to master it.‚Äù
While streaming an episode of ‚ÄúEmergency Meeting‚Äù on Rumble , the hackers flooded the main chatroom of Tate‚Äôs online university, spamming AI-generated images of Tate draped in the LGBTQ+ flag, emojis of the Transgender flag, a Feminist fist icon, and more.
Article continues after ad
Andrew Tate‚Äôs online university was hacked
‚Ä¢ Platform‚Äôs security was described as 'hilariously insecure'
‚Ä¢ ~325K email addresses as well as public & private chat logs were obtained
‚Ä¢ Hackers spammed private chatrooms with trans flags and an AI-generated image of Andrew Tate‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/VNA6cLl6E4
‚Äî Culture Crave üçø (@CultureCrave) November 22, 2024 The hackers provided a statement to the Daily Dot, claiming that after gaining access to Tate‚Äôs online University, they could ‚Äúupload emojis, delete attachments, crash everyone‚Äôs clients, and temporarily ban people‚Äù from the platform.
Article continues after ad In addition, it was reported that over 794,000 usernames of the site‚Äôs current and former members were leaked, over 320,000 email addresses were obtained, and the contents of 395 private chat servers were also obtained.
These leaked private chat logs contain conversations in which users of Andrew Tate‚Äôs online University were complaining about the ‚ÄúLGBTQ agenda.‚Äù
One such leaked private message reading is as follows:
‚ÄúLGBTQ agenda, the matrix. I live in a very good area with a very good home life, but I am sick of all this garbage happening here.‚Äù
Related: Logan Paul criticized for leaking TommyInnit DMs as viral ‚Äúbeef‚Äù gets personal Article continues after ad A source close to the breach detailed to the Daily Dot that the motive for this violation was ‚Äúhacktivism,‚Äù the same source claiming that the platform‚Äôs security was ‚Äúhilariously insecure.‚Äù
Article continues after ad Andrew Tate has yet to address this new security breach as of this writing. However, we‚Äôll update this article if he does issue a statement.

text: [M√≥nica Lizette Castellanos Osorio ](/autores/monica-lizette-castellanos-osorio) Primer fen√≥meno astron√≥mico en 2024: ¬øcu√°ndo y c√≥mo verlo en Colombia? En el 2024 se tendr√°n varios eventos astron√≥micos para que las personas los puedan ver. Las Cuadr√°ntidas son una lluvia de meteoros que ocurre entre el 1 y el 5 de enero, con su pico m√°ximo de actividad el 3 o 4 de enero. Es la primera lluvia de meteoros del a√±o en el hemisferio norte y es visible entre el 28 de diciembre y el 12 de enero. El radiante de las Cuadr√°ntidas se encuentra al norte de la constelaci√≥n de Bootes cerca de la cola de la Osa Mayor. Esta lluvia de meteoros puede tener una tasa de actividad por encima de los 120 meteoros por hora, lo que la convierte en una de las lluvias m√°s activas del a√±o junto a las Perseidas de agosto y las Gem√≠nidas de diciembre. Le puede interesar: [Mini agujeros negros pueden estar devorando estrellas](https://www.lafm.com.co/tecnologia/mini-agujeros-negros-pueden-estar-devorando-estrellas) Sin embargo, los meteoros no se ven tan a menudo como los meteoros de las otras dos lluvias debido a que su periodo de m√°xima actividad suele durar tan solo unas pocas horas y a las malas condiciones meteorol√≥gicas. author: Hayley Mignacca
title: Science for Living: Nicotine pouch use rising among teens; public health expert sounds alarm
text:
Oral nicotine pouches‚Äîsmall, smokeless, nearly invisible and placed between the lip and gum‚Äîare rapidly gaining popularity among teens, sparking new concerns from public health experts.
‚ÄúNicotine pouches are really discreet and easy to use. Young people use them without parents and teachers noticing,‚Äù said Elise Stevens, PhD, assistant professor of population & quantitative health sciences and director of the Center for Tobacco Treatment Research and Training at UMass Chan Medical School. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs part of what makes them so dangerous.‚Äù
What are the numbers showing?
Although oral nicotine pouches have been on the market since 2016, sales have surged dramatically in recent years. In 2016, approximately 100,000 units were sold. By 2020, that number soared to 46 million. The top-selling brands, Zyn, On!, Rogue and Velo, are owned by big tobacco companies.
Much like e-cigarettes, nicotine pouches have benefited from strategic marketing on social media platforms. Influencers, who often have large followings on social media, are promoting the products, sometimes without disclosing that they are being paid to do so. Early research shows that teens may trust and like the products more as a result of seeing them on social media, even when it is disclosed that the social media posts are paid advertising.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to understand why disclosure doesn‚Äôt deter interest,‚Äù said Dr. Stevens. ‚ÄúIt might be that teens see honesty as a form of trustworthiness. But either way, it‚Äôs making our job‚Äîto protect and inform young people‚Äîharder.‚Äù
What worries experts the most?
Beyond the rise in popularity, there‚Äôs concern over how early use of nicotine pouches may lead to addiction and even riskier behaviors.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs evidence that using one nicotine product makes you more likely to try others or at least view other nicotine and tobacco products as less harmful,‚Äù Stevens said. ‚ÄúEven if a teen switches from vaping to pouches, they‚Äôre still on a trajectory that could lead to smoking or other substance use.‚Äù
While pouches may carry fewer health risks than cigarettes or vapes, they are not harmless, especially for developing brains. Studies point to concerns over cognitive effects, memory disruption, cardiovascular disease, and oral and neurological problems.
What‚Äôs drawing teens in?
Teens say they like being able to conceal using the nicotine pouches since they place them under the lip. They also cite stress relief, peer influence and savvy marketing for what‚Äôs making the pouches more popular. With adolescent mental health struggles on the rise, many teens turn to nicotine as a coping tool, she said.
‚ÄúWe have a mental health epidemic among young people,‚Äù said Stevens. ‚ÄúAnd unfortunately, substances like nicotine become a way for teens to cope.‚Äù
In Massachusetts, flavored nicotine sales are banned from retail stores. Yet teens are finding creative ways to access flavored pouches: via older siblings, social media sales networks or across state lines.
‚ÄúSome kids are buying from older siblings or strangers online and we‚Äôre still trying to track exactly how widespread that is.‚Äù
Why is it so difficult to regulate?
Regulating nicotine pouches poses challenges, especially online. Social platforms are flooded with unmonitored promotional content, often fueled by complex influencer-marketing deals.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre seeing health misinformation explode online,‚Äù said Stevens. ‚ÄúMuch of the health content teens encounter on social media platforms is inaccurate and they‚Äôre using it to make real decisions.‚Äù
Additionally, the nicotine in these products is synthetic, which makes it harder to regulate within existing industry standards.
What can parents and educators do?
Because nicotine pouches are so easy to conceal, they often go unnoticed. Teachers and parents may only spot subtle signs like lip bulges or mild nausea. Relying on honest conversation and asking questions could be helpful.
‚ÄúHave open, nonjudgmental conversations. Kids are more likely to talk if they don‚Äôt feel punished. Education and support are key.‚Äù
What can help educate teens on this?
This rise in nicotine-pouch use highlights a deeper disconnect: the gap between public health messaging and actual teen behavior. Experts emphasize the need to meet youth where they are, especially online, with relatable stories and nuanced information.
‚ÄúTeens are pretty savvy,‚Äù Stevens reminds. ‚ÄúBut even the smartest of us can get duped by an influencer. I‚Äôve bought things from Instagram, too. That‚Äôs how powerful this stuff is.‚Äù
Related media:
Boston Globe: Are nicotine pouches like Zyn healthier than cigarettes? Here‚Äôs what you need to know.

author: Tigist Layne
title: North County Report: Escondido‚Äôs Budget Woes ‚Äì and a Possible Future Solution
text:
It‚Äôs that time of the year again.
Cities across San Diego County are finalizing their budgets for the fiscal year that begins in July. That‚Äôs been an especially burdensome process for some cities.
Enter Escondido, which has been struggling with an ongoing structural budget deficit and has been relying on one-time funding sources and temporary solutions to close budget gaps in the past few years.
That‚Äôs still the case for the upcoming fiscal year.
The City Council discussed the preliminary budget a couple weeks ago, and city staff presented a similar outlook to previous years. The city has to, once again, use one-time funding sources to close this year‚Äôs gap. Those sources are quickly running out.
The Budget
Escondido staff is projecting an average deficit of $18.2 million each year over the next 20 years. For the upcoming fiscal year, the city expects to use one-time funding sources and cost-reduction methods to close its budget gap.
The city will likely use around $4.8 million in Covid relief funds from the American Rescue Plan Act, which city leaders have tapped in previous years, to cover management contracts with the Escondido Public Library and the California Center for the Arts.
City staff said those Covid funds must be fully allocated by the end of 2024 and will no longer be a source of revenue for the city moving forward.
Another saving grace this year will come from the elimination of 10 full-time vacant positions, which reduced the budget by almost $1 million.
City leaders will also pull around $2.5 million from the city‚Äôs workers compensation fund to replace 39 police vehicles.
That money would typically come from the city‚Äôs Fleet Services Fund used to maintain, fuel and replace all city vehicles. The fund once included a pot of money for future vehicle purchases to regularly replace aging vehicles and equipment, but the city emptied it to close past budget gaps.
This is the first year since 2021 that the city didn‚Äôt tap its pension to balance its budget. The city created a pension trust fund in 2018 to set aside money to reduce pension bills and stabilize pension costs.
Pension liability is the difference between what the city owes retirees and the amount of money available to make those payments. Last year, Escondido had about $270 million in unfunded pension liability, and city leaders ended up pulling $1.5 million from its pension trust.
City Manager Sean McGlynn warned the City Council recently that the budget will only get more difficult to balance as the years go on.
Without existing funds to raid, there may be significant cuts to city services as early as next fiscal year.
‚ÄúEven though we‚Äôre finding a way to manage through our current circumstances, there are looming deficits that we can‚Äôt keep pace with,‚Äù McGlynn said.
A few city services and departments have taken a hit over the past few years as city leaders try to reduce costs without sacrificing public safety and other priorities.
Last year, I
reported that the biggest impact has been to Escondido‚Äôs maintenance and public works. That includes upkeep of parks, playgrounds, libraries, recreation centers, pools, streets, sidewalks, bridges, storm drains, fleet and other city facilities.
City finance director Christina Holmes
told me in May 2023 that city staff estimates that more than $8 million of maintenance has been deferred annually since about 2008.
Holmes said then that the annual $8 million in deferred maintenance compounds. So, a park or recreation center that has not been upgraded could remain that way until the city finds the funds to do so. In the meantime, that leaves roughly $128 million in backlogged fixes that Escondido still can‚Äôt pay for.
The City Council is set to approve the final budget for the upcoming fiscal year on June 19.
Sales Tax Measure, Round Three
Escondido residents will likely get another opportunity to vote on a sales tax measure this November.
A
citizens‚Äô coalition called Escondido Citizens for Safety announced last week that it‚Äôs collected and submitted more than the required 7,600 signatures needed to qualify the measure. It reported collecting close to 12,000 signatures.
The coalition is led by the Escondido Police Officers Association and the Escondido Firefighters Association and is supported by an array of community leaders, business, labor and public safety organizations.
The measure will ask residents to vote on a one-cent sales tax increase that would sunset after 20 years. It also calls for a Citizens‚Äô Oversight Committee to oversee how new revenue is spent.
The coalition says the measure would bring in an estimated $25 million each year in new revenue to the city to close its structural budget deficit.
Escondido has had similar ballot measures twice before that were projected to raise around $20 million annually. The City Council
didn‚Äôt approve the first one in 2020, and voters rejected the second one at the ballot box in 2022.
In Other News
- ICYMI: The Escondido Democratic Club is
no longer supportingfour Democratic members of Palomar Health‚Äôs board who voted in favor of a new management agreement that the club‚Äôs leadership says could greatly reduce public access and transparency. (Voice of San Diego)
- Speaking of Palomar Health, the healthcare district has agreed to a $250,000 settlement after disclosing to the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency that
fentanyl was divertedfrom automatic-dispensing equipment at its cardiac catheterization lab in Escondido. (Union-Tribune)
- SANDAG has
reduced the number of possible routesfor Del Mar‚Äôs train tunnel to three options. (Union-Tribune) Related: Read more about the plan to move a portion of the train tracks that run along Del Mar‚Äôs coast into an underground tunnel here. (Voice of San Diego)
